{| class="infobox geography" style="width: 20em" |+ Geography of Kosovo{{Small|{{efn|name=status}}}}''' |- | colspan=2 | [[File:Kosovo_map-en1.svg|border|320px]] |- | '''[[Continent]]''' || [[Europe]] |- | '''[[Subregion]]''' || [[Balkan Peninsula]]
[[Southeastern Europe]] |- | '''[[Area]]'''
 - Total
 - Land (%)
 - Water (%) |
{{convert|10887|sqkm|abbr=on}}
99
1 |- | '''Land borders''' || [[Albania]] {{convert|113,551|km|abbr=on}},
[[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] {{convert|170,772|km|abbr=on}},
[[Montenegro]] {{convert|79,165|km|abbr=on}},
Serbia {{convert|380,068|km|abbr=on}} |- | '''Highest point''' || [[Gjeravica]]
{{convert|2,656|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} |- | '''Lowest point''' || [[White Drin|River of White Drin]]
{{convert|297|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} |- | '''Longest river''' || River of White Drin
{{convert|122|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} |- | '''Largest lake''' || [[Lake Gazivoda]]
{{convert|9.2|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} |- | '''[[Climate]]''': || [[Temperate climate|Temperate Zone]]
[[Continental climate|Continental]] and [[Mediterranean climate|Mediterranean]] |- | '''[[Terrain]]''': || [[Mountain]]s, [[Hill]]s, [[Forest]], [[Urban area|urban]] |} '''[[Kosovo]]''' is a [[smallest countries|small]] and [[landlocked country|landlocked disputed territory]] in [[Southeastern Europe]]. The country is strategically positioned in the center of the [[Balkan Peninsula]] enclosed by [[Montenegro]] to the west, Serbia to the north and east, the [[Republic of Macedonia]] to the southeast, and [[Albania]] to the southwest. It has no direct access to the [[Mediterranean Sea]] but its rivers flow into three seas, the [[Adriatic Sea|Adriatic]], [[Aegean Sea|Aegean]] and [[Black Sea]]. The country possesses impressive and contrasting [[landscape]]s determined by the [[climate]] along with the [[geology]] and [[hydrology]]. Both, the [[Albanian Alps]] and [[Sharr Mountains]], are the most defining feature of the country and simultaneously the most biodiverse regions of Kosovo. As far as the central region, the plains of [[Dukagjini Plain|Dukagjin]] and [[Kosovo field (Kosovo)|Kosovo]] stretches over the west and east, respectively. The country is a quite rich country for its [[water source]]s, there are many long and short [[river]]s, as well as [[Artificial Lake|artificial]] and [[natural lake]]s around the country. Most of the rivers that rise in Kosovo have their mouths outside the country's territory in the Adriatic, Aegean and Black Sea.{{cite web |author1=Gani Gashia, Florim Isufi, Shpejtim Bulliqia, Ibrahim Ramadania |title=Correlation between discharge, river Basin surface and rainfall quantity in Kosova |url=http://publisher-connector.core.ac.uk/resourcesync/data/elsevier/pdf/096/aHR0cDovL2FwaS5lbHNldmllci5jb20vY29udGVudC9hcnRpY2xlL3BpaS9zMTg3NzA0MjgxMTAxMjczMA%3D%3D.pdf |website=publisher-connector.core.ac.uk |pages=1–5 |language=English |format=PDF |quote=Kosovo waters flows towards the Adriatic, Aegean and Black Sea.}} The longest river is the [[Drini i Bardhë]], while the shortest river is the [[Lumëbardhi i Prizrenit]]. The climate of the country is mostly defined by its geographical location in the southeastern part of the [[european continent]] and strongly influenced by the seas in the west, south and east. It enjoys a combination of a [[continental climate]] and a [[mediterranean climate]], with four distinct seasons. Kosovo is characterised by rich [[flora]] and [[fauna]], and a wide array of [[ecosystem]]s and [[habitat]]s considering its relatively small area.{{cite web |title=Kosovo Biodiversity Assessment |url=https://www.ammk-rks.net/repository/docs/Kosovo-BiodiversityAssessment.pdf |website=ww.ammk-rks.net |pages=1–66 |language=English |format=PDF}} The country's [[biodiversity]] is conserved in two [[national park]]s and [[Protected areas of Kosovo|hundreds]] of other [[protected area]]s of different categories. The remote and [[Forests of Kosovo|forested]] regions are primarily inhabited by important species that are fast becoming rare in [[Southern Europe]], amongst them the [[brown bear]], [[grey wolf]], [[Balkan lynx|lynx]] and [[golden eagle]]. == Territory == === Borders === The [[landlocked country]] of [[Kosovo]] lies in the heart of the [[Balkan Peninsula]] in [[Southeastern Europe]]. It borders the countries of [[Montenegro]] to the west, Serbia to the north and east, the [[Republic of Macedonia]] to the southeast and [[Albania]] to the southwest.[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/kv.html], CIA - The World Factbook The land area of the country is {{convert|10,887|km2}}, being the [[List of countries and dependencies by area|161st]] largest country in the world. The border between Kosovo and [[Albania]] stretches for a total of {{convert|113,551|km|abbr=on}} and is situated along the southwestern edge of the country.{{cite web |author1=Ministria e Punëve të Brendshme e Kosovës |title=STRATEGJIA KOMBËTARE E REPUBLIKËS SË KOSOVËS PËR MENAXHIMIN E INTEGRUAR TË KUFIRIT |url=http://www.kryeministri-ks.net/repository/docs/Strategjia_Kombetare_per_MIK_2013-2018.pdf |website=mpb-ks.org |pages=1–93 |language=Albanian |format=PDF}} This border is significantly marked by the [[Albanian Alps]], the [[Koritnik]] and [[Gjallica]] Mountains, which occupy the vast expanse of land between the countries. The border between Kosovo and the [[Republic of Macedonia]] stretches for a total of {{convert|170,772|km|abbr=on}}. This border is situated along the southeastern edge of the country, whereby the majority of this border follows the [[Sharr Mountains]]. The border between Kosovo and [[Montenegro]] measures at only {{convert|79,165|km|abbr=on}} in length, making it the shortest border in the country. This border is rugged and mountainous associated with the Albanian Alps. The border between Kosovo and Serbia stretches for a total of {{convert|380,068|km|abbr=on}} and is situated along the northern and eastern edge of the country. == Physical geography == === Topography === {{See also|List of mountains of Kosovo|l1=Mountains of Kosovo}} {{multiple image |align=right |total_width=360 |image_style=border:none; |image1=Sllatinë.jpg |alt1=Plain of Kosovo |caption1=The [[Kosovo plain|Plain of Kosovo]] stretches in east.|image2=Brod_Dragash.jpg |alt2=Sharr Mountains |caption2=The [[Sharr Mountains]] stretches in the southeast.}} The country of [[Kosovo]] features notable diversity with the [[landscape]] and [[relief]]. Framed along its borders by mountain ranges, as for instance the [[Albanian Alps]], and the [[Sharr Mountains]], the country's [[topography]] is clearly defined by two main plains, the plains of [[Dukagjini Plain|Dukagjini]] and [[Kosovo plain|Kosovo]]. Most of the country is mountainous and hilly. The southern and southeastern edge is distinguished by the Sharr Mountains.{{cite web |title=SHARR/ŠAR PLANINA – KORAB – DEŠAT/DESHAT |url=http://www.envsec.org/publications/Feasibility%20study%20on%20establishing%20a%20transboundary%20protected%20area.%20Sharr-Sar%20Planina-Korab-Desat-Deshat.pdf |website=envsec.org |pages=1–132 |language=English |format=PDF}} The Albanian Alps dominate the western edge as they offer the highest mountain of Kosovo, the [[Gjeravica]].{{cite web |author1=Zeqir Veselaj |title=Bjeshkët e Nemuna perla natyrore e Kosovës |url=http://documents.rec.org/publications/Bjeshket_e_Nemuna_AL.pdf |website=documents.rec.org |pages=29–32 |language=Albanian |date=2010}}{{cite web |author1=Ministria e Mjedisit dhe Planifikimit Hapësinor - Instituti i Kosovës për Mbrojtjen e Natyrës |title=STUDIM MBI ARSYESHMËRINË E SHPALLJES SË TERRITORIT TË BJESHKËVE TË NEMUNA PARK NACIONAL |url=https://www.ammk-rks.net/repository/docs/Studimi_per_Bjeshket_e_Nemuna.pdf |website=ammk-rks.net |pages=13–14 |language=Albanian |format=PDF}} Often referred to as the [[Bjeshkët e Nemuna]], the region is considered to be among the most inaccessible mountain range in [[Europe]] and the wildest range on the [[Balkan Peninsula]], which is best described in their name. [[Bjeshkët e Nemuna National Park]] and [[Sharr Mountains National Park]] were established to protect the landscape, scenery and natural environment of the country.{{cite web|title=PËR PARKUN KOMBËTAR "BJESHKËT E NEMUNA"|url=http://www.ammk-rks.net/repository/docs/Ligji_per_Parkun_Kombetar_-Bjeshket_e_Nemuna_Final.pdf|website=ammk-rks.net|language=Albanian|format=PDF}}{{cite web|title=PËR PARKUN KOMBËTAR "SHARRI"|url=http://www.ammk-rks.net/repository/docs/Ligji_per_Parkun_Kombetar-Sharri__FINAL.pdf|website=ammk-rks.net|language=Albanian|format=PDF}} They represent the most important regions of [[vegetation]] and [[biodiversity]] in the country, because they provide excellent conditions for a great [[wildlife|wild]] and [[plant]] life.{{cite web|title=Qenan Maxhuni: Biodiversiteti i Kosoves|url=http://www.ammk-rks.net/repository/docs/Biodiversiteti_i_Kosoves.pdf|publisher=AKMM/IKMN|accessdate=23 February 2013|language=Albanian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303215939/http://www.ammk-rks.net/repository/docs/Biodiversiteti_i_Kosoves.pdf|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |title=VLERAT E TRASHËGIMISË NATYRORE TË KOSOVËS |url=http://www.ammk-rks.net/repository/docs/Vlerat_e_trashegimis_natyrore_te_Kosoves.pdf |website=ammk-rks.net |language=Albanian |format=PDF |date=2005}} The [[Kopaonik|Kopaonik Mountains]] extend in the northern edge of the country and further run into central Serbia. They are characterized by its [[mineral]] wealth, especially abundant by [[lead]] and [[zinc]], making it one of the richest regions in [[Europe]]. This is due to the diversity of its [[geological|geological structure]], particularly with the new [[vulcanization]] during the [[Tertiary Period|tertiary period]].http://www.trepca.net/histori/020113-shala-bajgores-ne-veshtrimin-historik.htm[http://www.showcaves.com/english/yu/showcaves/Mermerna.html Mermerna Pecina], Tony Oldham, 2002Around Kosovo: It's Better to See it Once Than Hear About it 100 Times, Valerii Petrushka === Hydrography === {{See also|List of rivers of Kosovo|List of lakes in Kosovo|l1=Rivers|l2=Lakes of Kosovo}} [[File:Liqeni i madh ne bjeshket e Nemuna.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Lake Leqinat|Lake of Leqinat]] within the [[Bjeshkët e Nemuna National Park]] in the west of Kosovo.]] A landlocked country, there are several notable [[river]]s and [[lake]]s within the country's borders. The [[drainage basin]] of the [[Black Sea]] comprises 50.7 percent of the territory of the country and totals {{convert|5520|sqkm}}, which makes it the largest in Kosovo.{{cite web |author1=Ministria e Mjedisit dhe Planifikimit Hapësinor - Instituti i Kosovës për Mbrojtjen e Natyrës |title=Report The State of Water in Kosovo R |url=https://www.ammk-rks.net/repository/docs/raporti_ujerave_2010-angl.pdf |website=ammk-rks.net |location=Prishtina |pages=31–39 |language=English |date=2010}} The main rivers in the section of the country of the river basin are the rivers of [[Ibar (river)|Ibar]] and [[Sitnica]]. In contrast, 43.5 percent of the country's territory is encompassed by the drainage basin of the [[Adriatic Sea]]. The area includes the largest rivers flowing in the country, the [[White Drin]] with its tributaries [[Erenik]] and [[Dečani Bistrica|Lumëbardhi i Decanit]]. The rest belongs to the [[Aegean Sea]] drainage basin, where the largest river by far is the [[Lepenac]]. The [[Bifurcation of Nerodimka river|Nerodimka]] is of particular significance because it represents Europe's only instance of a river [[River bifurcation|bifurcation]] flowing into two seas, the Black and Aegean Sea. The bifurcation of the river is considered to be an artificial phenomenon, but created under extremely favorable natural conditions. A number of natural lakes are located in the mountain ranges at various altitudes amongst them the [[Gjeravica Lake|Gjeravica]], [[Lake Leqinat|Leqinat]], [[Jazhincë Lake|Jazhincë]], and [[Zemra Lake|Zemra]]. Kosovo also does have a large number of [[karst springs]], [[Thermal water|thermal]] and mineral water springs.[http://www.kosovo-mining.org/kosovoweb/en/kosovo/hydrology.html] Independent Commission for Mines and Minerals of Kosovo The main lakes are [[Gazivoda Lake]] (380 million m³) in the north-western part, [[Radoniq lake]] (113 million m³) in the south-west part, [[Batlava Lake]] (40 million m³) and [[Badovc Lake]] (26 million m³) in the north-east part. Other smaller scenic lakes include [[Zemra Lake]], [[Đeravica Lake]] and [[Liqenat Lake]]. == Biodiversity == {{main|Biodiversity of Kosovo}} {{see|Protected areas of Kosovo}} {{multiple image |align=right |total_width=360 |image_style=border:none; |image1=Long_ridge_of_Pashallore.jpg |alt1=Sharr Mountains National Park |caption1=The [[Sharr Mountains National Park]] stretches in the southeast|image2=Parku_Kombëtar_Bjeshkët_Nemuna_,_Liqeni_i_madh_ne_Liqenat_,_Rugove.jpg |alt2=Bjeshkët e Nemuna National Park |caption2=The [[Bjeshkët e Nemuna National Park]] stretches in the west.}} Kosovo is characterised by a diverse [[biodiversity]] and an abundance of different [[ecosystem]]s and [[habitat]]s with a remarkable exponential value.{{cite web |title=Kosovo Biodiversity Assessment |url=https://www.ammk-rks.net/repository/docs/Kosovo-BiodiversityAssessment.pdf |website=ammk-rks.net |pages=1–66 |language=English |format=PDF |date=2003}} It is located at the crossroads of several [[biogeographical region]]s and therefore has specific [[climate]], [[geological]], [[hydrological]] and [[Geomorphology|morphological]] conditions. In terms of [[phytogeography]], the land area of Kosovo lies within the [[Boreal Kingdom]], specifically within the [[Illyria]]n province of the [[Circumboreal Region]]. Its territory can be conventionally subdivided into four terrestrial [[ecoregion]]s of the [[Palearctic ecozone]], amongst them the [[Balkan mixed forests|Balkan]] and [[Dinaric Mountains mixed forests|Dinaric]] mixed forests. Kosovo is particularly rich in remote and mountainous landscapes endowed with [[forest]]s. They are home to a large number of the country's [[animal]] species, including many [[endangered species]]. Kosovo is one of the rare countries in Europe with populations of rare species, the [[golden eagle]], the [[brown bear]], the [[grey wolf]] and the [[Balkan lynx|lynx]].{{cite web |title=Brown Bear Conservation Action Plan for Europe |url=http://www2.nina.no/lcie_new/pdf/634989771612454147_IUCN%20Euro%20bear%20action%20plans.pdf |website=nina.no |language=English |format=PDF}}{{cite web |title=Action Plan for Grey Wolf Canis lupus Conservation and Management |url=https://www.daba.gov.lv/upload/File/DOC_SAP/AP_grey_wolf_17_EN.pdf |website=daba.gov.lv |language=English |format=PDF |date=2017}}{{cite web |title=STATSU AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE BALKAN LYNX (Lynx lynx martinoi MIRIĆ, 1978) AND ITS PREY |url=http://www.catsg.org/fileadmin/filesharing/3.Conservation_Center/3.2._Status_Reports/Eurasian_lynx/Melovski_2012_Status_and_distribution_of_the_Balkan_lynx.pdf |website=catsg.org |language=English |format=PDF}} The country has only two designated [[national park]]s.{{cite web|title=Overview of Nature Protection Progress in Kosovo|url=http://www.landscapeonline.de/wp-content/uploads/DOI103097-LO201545.pdf|website=landscapeonline.de|page=6|language=Albanian|format=PDF}} The [[Bjeshkët e Nemuna National Park]] in western and southwestern Kosovo is the largest national park by area in the country. The park encompasses {{convert|63028|hectare|km2|}} of the mountainous region of the [[Albanian Alps]]. The [[Sharr Mountains National Park]] was established to protect the spectacular scenery of southeastern Kosovo. It includes the country's section of the [[Sharr Mountains]] that cuts across the landscape along the border between Kosovo and Macedonia. == Climate == {{main|Climate of Kosovo}} Kosovo is located between the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and mountainous regions of Southeast [[Europe]], on the [[Balkan Peninsula]]. This geographic location gives the country its large annual temperature range. Summer temperature highs can reach +{{convert|30|°C|°F}}, winter's temperatures as low as {{convert|-10|°C|°F}}.[http://www.kosovo-mining.org/kosovoweb/en/kosovo/geography.html Geography] According to the [[Strahler]] classification map the climate in Kosovo is considered moist continental.Strahler & Strahler. (2006).Introducing Physical Geography, Boston:John Wiley & Sons Inc. The country experiences warm summers and cold and snowy winters. The climatic area of the [[Ibar (river)|Ibar]] valley is influenced by continental [[air mass]]es. For this reason, in this part of the region, the [[winter]]s are colder with medium temperatures above {{convert|-10|C|F}}, but sometimes down to {{convert|-26|C|F}}. The [[summer]]s are very hot with average temperatures of {{convert|20|C|F}}, sometimes up to {{convert|37|C|F}}. This area is characterized by a dry climate and a total annual precipitation of 600 mm per year, approximately. The climatic area of [[Metohija]], which includes the watershed of the [[White Drin]] river, is influenced very much by the hot air masses, which cross the [[Adriatic Sea]]. Medium temperatures during winter range from {{convert|0.5|C|F}} to sometimes {{convert|22.8|C|F}}. The average annual precipitation of this climatic area is about {{convert|700|mm|in|abbr=on}} per year. The winter is characterized by heavy [[snow]]falls. The climatic area of the [[mountain]]s and forest parts is characterised by a typical forest clime, that is associated with heavy [[rain]]falls ({{convert|900|to|1300|mm|in|abbr=on}} per year), and summers that are very short and cold, and winters that are cold and with a lot of [[snow]]. Finally, it can be stated that the Kosovo territory is characterised by a sunny climate with variable temperature and humidity conditions.{{cite web|url=http://www.kosovo-mining.org/kosovoweb/en/kosovo/climate.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527212027/http://www.kosovo-mining.org/kosovoweb/en/kosovo/climate.html |archivedate=2014-05-27 |df= }} == See also == {{Commons category|Geography of Kosovo}} * [[Climate of Kosovo]] * [[Biodiversity of Kosovo]] * [[Forests of Kosovo]] == Notes == {{notes | notes = {{efn | name = status | {{Kosovo-note}} }} }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Navboxes | title = [[File:Coat_of_arms_of_Kosovo.svg|20x20px]] Topics related to Geography of [[Kosovo]] | titlestyle = color:black; background-color:white; |list1={{Kosovo topics}} {{Geography of Europe}} }} {{Portal bar|Geography|Kosovo}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Geography Of Kosovo}} [[Category:Geography of Kosovo| ]] [[Category:Environment of Kosovo]]

The '''geology of [[Estonia]]''' is the study of rocks, minerals, water, landforms and geologic history in Estonia. The crust is part of the East European Craton and formed beginning in the [[Paleoproterozoic]] nearly two billion years ago. Shallow marine environments predominated in Estonia, producing extensive natural resources from organic matter such as [[oil shale]] and [[phosphorite]]. The [[Mesozoic]] and much of the [[Cenozoic]] are not well-preserved in the rock record, although the glaciations during the [[Pleistocene]] buried deep valleys in sediment, rechanneled streams and left a landscape of extensive lakes and peat bogs. <ref>{{cite book |author=Moores, E.M.; Fairbridge, Rhodes W.|year=1997|title=Encyclopedia of European & Asian Regional Geology|publisher=Springer|p=192-202}}</ref >
==Stratigraphy, Tectonics & Geologic History== [[File:Cambrian blue clay in Voka.jpg|thumb|Cambrian blue clay outcrop at beach of Gulf of Finland in Voka]]
Estonia is part of the [[East European Craton]], with an average continental crust thickness between 40 and 64 kilometers. The crust consolidated during the [[Svecofennian Orogeny]] in the late [[Paleoproterozoic]], nearly two billion years ago.
The contact between the crystalline basement and overlying rock dips gently to the south. Late [[Proterozoic]] and early and middle [[Paleozoic]] sedimentary rocks on the north coast of Estonia are 100 to 200 meters thick, reaching up to 500 to 800 meters thick in the Gulf of Riga and the southeast. The [[Baltic Syncline]] and [[Moscow Syncline]] are deeply buried structures within the Russian Platform, with three to five kilometers of sediments. They are linked by the [[Latvian Saddle]], which is shallower with two kilometers of sediment. Precambrian rocks do not outcrop anywhere in Estonia, but are present in the subsurface. {{sfn| Moores, E.M.; Fairbridge, Rhodes W.|1997|p=194-196}}
===Paleozoic (541-251 million years ago)=== Except for artificial outcrops in oil shale and phosphorite strip mines, the only outcrops of Paleozoic rocks are found in a few river valleys, coastal cliffs on the Baltic and the shores of lake Vortsjarv and Peipsi.
During the [[Ordovician]] and [[Silurian]], a shallow marine environment predominated in Estonia, depositing organic-rich black carbonate shale which later generated oil shale. Reef limestones and backreef [[dolomite]] contributed material to the carbonaceous shale. Silurian sedimentation took place during a retreat in sea levels, bringing a break in sediment deposition.
In the [[Early Devonian]], sedimentation continued. The Old Red sandstones deposited in the [[Middle Devonian]] in a nearshore marine environment from sand and silt, shed during the [[Caledonian orogeny]] onto the Fennoscandian continental plain. A few carbonate rocks capped the Devonian in the southeast.
The sedimentary rocks preserve extensive fossils and tens of thousands of specimens have been gathered at the University of Tartu and Institute of Geology. [[Brachiopod]], mollusk, [[trilobite]], [[ostracod]], [[bryozoan]], [[graptolite]] and [[stromatoporoid]] fossils are especially common. <ref>{{cite article |author=Loydell, Kaljo, Mannik |year=1998|title=Integrated biostratigraphy of the lower Silurian of the Ohesaare core, Saaremaa, Estonia|publisher=Geological Magazine|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/geological-magazine/article/integrated-biostratigraphy-of-the-lower-silurian-of-the-ohesaare-core-saaremaa-estonia/AE6BA198A1B3A22CEB12C2218A1D848F}}</ref> Most natural resources in Estonia formed from fossil remains, including [[kukersite]] and phosphorite deposits formed from shells.
Through the Devonian, the continent [[Baltica]], which included Estonia, drifted from the South Pole to north of the Equator and was influenced by glacier-related changes in sea level. Deformation of rocks from weak, regional tectonic stresses leads to some [[anticline]] folds and fluid migration in the rocks, which generate [[metasomatic]] dolomite limestone, zinc mineralization and lead-sulfide deposits. The [[Kardla astrobleme]] on Hiiumaa Island formed from an asteroid impact 455 million years ago, and Estonia has three other small meteorite craters, less than 110 meters in diameters in the bedrock. {{sfn| Moores, E.M.; Fairbridge, Rhodes W.|1997|p=194-197}}
===Mesozoic-Cenozoic (251 million years ago to present)=== The [[Mesozoic]] and much of the [[Cenozoic]] are poorly attested in Estonia. However, extensive sediments and landforms remain from the last 2.5 million years of the [[Quaternary]].
A thin blanket of Quaternary sediments covers the plains of western Estonia. The Baltic Sea and Gulf of Finland are relatively deep erosional features in the bedrock, as are the lake basins of Vortsjarv and Peipsi, which were deepened by glaciers during the [[Pleistocene]]. Before and in-between glaciations, a network of deep valleys formed, up to 145 meters below sea levels, connecting the Baltic and the Gulf of Finland. However, more recent sedimentation has disguised old valleys which do not appear as a major part of present day topography.
Glacial debris is less than five kilometers thick in northern Estonia and parts of the country underlain by limestone and dolomite have [[karst]] processes and hardly any remnants of glaciation. The Haanja Heights and Otepaa Heights have up to 100 meters of glacial sediment, or up to 207 meters in the Abja Valley in the south. Quaternary geologists define five major till layers, separated by interglacial pollen assemblages.
Moraines are often up to tens of kilometers long and more than 50 meters in height, such as the Laane-Saaremaa terminal moraine. [[Kame]] fields and [[eskers]] are also common, particularly on the Pandivere Upland and the West Estonian Lowland. Glacial retreat began around 13,000 years ago and ended by around 11,000 years ago. However, ice-dammed lakes and isostatic rebound in the region played an important role in geomorphology for several more millennia. The Baltic Ice Lake gave way to the Yoldia Sea, Ancylus Lake and Littorina Sea, followed by the Limnea Sea. The land of Estonia rose 65 meters in a span of only 2450 years and has risen an additional 50 meters in the past 10,000 years.
Deglaciation led to the formation of river valleys and 20 to 40 percent of downcutting in rivers in the south happened during a short span after glaciation. Estonia has 1500 lakes and 20,000 peat bogs, although the number of lakes was three times as many at the start of the [[Holocene]]. {{sfn| Moores, E.M.; Fairbridge, Rhodes W.|1997|p=197-198}}
==Natural resource geology== [[File:VKG Ojamaa kaevandus.jpg|thumb|VKG Ojamaa mine for oil shale extraction, using an Atlas Copco Scooptram ST7 underground loader]] [[Oil shale in Estonia]] remains a major part of the economy and throughout the 1950s, '60s, '70s, '80s and early '90s, geologists extensively prospected oil shale resources, with peak production in 1980. [[Phosphorite]] mining was also an important activity in Estonia through the 1980s, prompting the so-called [[Phosphorite War]] in 1987 when the Estonian public opposed the expansion of mining efforts, and the implicit threat of additional Russian miners being sent to the region. The major phosphorite mine at Maardu closed in 1991 due to its environmental impact.
[[File:Turbaraba.jpg|thumb|Peat extraction in Hiiumaa, September, 2013]] Estonia has 165,000 mires (including 20,000 peat bogs), each with an area of one hectare or greater. About 1500 are commercially important and most have thicknesses of three to seven meters, with a maximum of 16.7 meters in the Haanja Heights. Lake chalk is sometimes used to neutralize high acidity and for art material. Estonia also has iron ore in the crystalline basement, pyrite and [[glauconite]] and, as well as lead and zinc sulfide ore. Granite rock near Tallinn is often extracted for road work.
Estonia also has extensive clays dating to the Cambrian, Devonian and Quaternary, which are widely used in ceramics and cement. Limestone is also used as a raw material for the chemical, pulp, paper, building stone and glass industries, while dolomite is sometimes used for facing stones. Gyttja lake mud occurs in 121 lakes, with up to three billion cubic meters of reserves and a large deposit of 45 million tons at Varska. Lake mud can be used for medical purposes, or in fertilizers. {{sfn| Moores, E.M.; Fairbridge, Rhodes W.|1997|p=200-202}}
==History of geologic research== Estonian geologists have developed The Book of Primeval Nature, chronicling landforms in the country. The Kaali meteorite crater on Saaremaa Island was the first geologic site slated for protection after its recognition in 1937.
The Institute of Geology of the Academy of Sciences was organized in 1947, followed by the founding of the Geological Survey of Estonia and the Institute of Geology in 1957. Since the 1950s, Estonian organizations drilled tens of thousands of boreholes through the sedimentary cover, in some cases reaching more than 500 meters deep into the crystalline basement rock.
The Geological Survey of Estonia completed mapping of Paleozoic bedrock and Quaternary sediments by 1975. Additional maps of hydrogeology, geomorphology, engineering geology and even geoecology have been completed since then. Up until 1990, all geologic publications were written in Russian.

{{distinguish|Herbert B. Gregory}} '''Herbert Ernest Gregory''' (1869–1952)<ref>[http://nwda.orbiscascade.org/ark:/80444/xv18865 Guide to the Herbert E. Gregory photograph collection 1900–1944]</ref> was a [[Yale University]] [[geology|geologist]] well known for his early 20th-century explorations of the [[Colorado Plateau]] in [[Arizona]] and [[Utah]]. One of his most important works is ''Colorado Plateau Region'', published by the [[United States Geological Survey]] on the occasion of the [[United States]] sponsoring the 16th [[International Geological Congress]].<ref name=Martin!983>{{cite journal|last=Martin|first=Geoffrey J.|title=Geography, Geographers and Yale University, c. 1770-1970|journal=Geography in New England Special Publication of the New England/St. Lawrence Valley Geographical Society|year=1983|pages=2–9|url=http://old.geog.psu.edu/hog/depthistory_files/Yale_Geog_in_NE.pdf|accessdate=19 October 2012}}</ref>
Gregory was a student at [[Harvard University]] of American [[geography|geographer]] [[William Morris Davis]]{{fact|date=May 2017}}. He was the director of the geology department at Yale University, where he worked to expand the department to include a human geography emphasis. From 1919 to 1936 he served as director of the [[Bishop Museum]] in [[Hawaii]], where, in 1961, after his death, he was honored by a medal named after him. The Herbert E. Gregory Medal is awarded every four years to a leading scientist in the Pacific Region.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Herbert E. Gregory Medal |url=http://www.bishopmuseum.org/media/2011/pr11022.html |accessdate=19 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004042622/http://bishopmuseum.org/media/2011/pr11022.html |archivedate=4 October 2012 |df= }}</ref>
His seminal work included mapping much of the bedrock geology of the [[Colorado Plateau]], particularly in geologic monographs concentrating on what is now the [[Navajo Nation]] in northeastern [[Arizona]] and southeastern [[Utah]]. Among many other achievements, he was the first to name and describe the [[Upper Triassic]] [[Chinle Formation]], which is famous for preserving extensive fossil evidence of [[Late Triassic]] terrestrial ecosystems, including [[petrified wood|fossilized logs]].
In 1931, Gregory published the first [[geologic map]] of the [[Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument]].<ref name="Science">{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-79476904.html|title=Utah's Fossil Trove Beckons, And Tests, Researchers|last=Stokstad|first=Erik|date=October 5, 2001|work=Science|accessdate=19 October 2012}}</ref> Gregory stated that no fossils had been discovered; however, many were later found.<ref name="Science" />

page.title: International Soil Reference and Information Centre

revision.text:
(ISRIC - World Soil Information)
==Mission== '''[http://www.isric.org ISRIC - World Soil Information]''', legally registered as the International Soil Reference and Information Centre, is an independent, science-based foundation. The institute was founded in 1966 following a recommendation of the International Society of Soil Science (ISSS, now [[International Union of Soil Sciences]]| (IUSS)) and the [[UNESCO|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO)]]. It has a mission to serve the international community with information about the world’s [[soil]] resources to help addressing major [[global issues]].<ref>{{cite report|author-last1=IYPE|year=2005|title=Soil - Earth’s living skin, International Year of Planet Earth, Tronsheim (NO)|pages= 16| url=http://iuss.boku.ac.at/files/soilbrochureype.pdf}}</ref>
==Main focus areas== Together with partners, ISRIC produces, gathers, compiles and serves quality-assessed soil information at global, national and regional levels. Work is organised according to 4 workstreams: Setting Standards and References, Soil Information Brokering, Capacity Building and Advocacy, and Derived products.
ISRIC stimulate the use of this information to address global challenges through capacity building, awareness raising and direct cooperation with users and clients. Details are provided on the following website [https://www.isric.org/about/vision-mission].
Recent developments at ISRIC, and the|World Soil Museum, are succinctly described in a series of Annual Highlights.<ref>{{cite report|author-last1=ISRIC|year=2018|title=Highlights 2016-2017|pages= 16| url=https://www.isric.org/sites/default/files/isric_highlights_2016_2017.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite report|author-last1=ISRIC|year=2016|title=Highlights 2014-2015|pages= 9| url=http://library.wur.nl/isric/fulltext/isricu_i34285_001.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite report|author-last1=ISRIC|year=2014|title=Highlights 2012-2013|pages= 12| url=http://library.wur.nl/isric/fulltext/isricu_i34286_001.pdf}}</ref>
==Data holdings and webservices== Our reference collection includes country documentation (reports, maps and slides), soil specimens (monoliths, samples, thin sections, hand specimens). Physical examples of our soil monolith collection are on permanent display in the [[World Soil Museum]].
[[File:New World Soil Meuseum in Wageningen.JPG|thumb|Building of the World Soil Museum, Wageningen campus]]
ISRIC also manages and develops geo-referenced databases (point, polygon, and raster). Since 2010, ISRIC has been developing a framework for safeguarding, handling and producing open soil data [https://www.isric.org/explore/soil-information-brokering]. Freely available products provided by ISRIC include a set of standardised soil profile data for the world served from WoSIS<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Batjes, Niels H. |author2=Ribeiro, Eloi |author3=van Oostrum, Ad |author4=Leenaars, Johan |author5=Hengl, Tom |author6=Mendes de Jesus, Jorge|year=2017|title=WoSIS: providing standardised soil profile data for the world|journal=Earth System Science Data|volume=9|pages= 1–9 |doi=10.5194/essd-9-1-2017|url=http://www.earth-syst-sci-data.net/9/1/2017/}}</ref> and a collection of updatable soil property and class maps of the world at 1 km<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Hengl, Tom |author2=Mendes de Jesus, Jorge |author3=McMillan, R.A. |author4=Batjes, Niels H. |author5=Heuvelink, G.B.M. |author6=Ribeiro, Eloi C. |author7=Samuel-Rosa, Allesandro |author8=Kempen, Bas |author9=Leenaars, J.G.B. |author10=Walsh, M.G. |author11=Ruiperez Gonzalez, Maria G. |year=2014|title=SoilGrids1km — global soil information based on automated mapping|journal=PLoS ONE |volume=9 |issue=8 |pages=e105992 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0105992|url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0105992}}</ref> and 250 m<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Hengl, Tom|author2=Mendes de Jesus, Jorge |author3=Heuvelink, G.B.M. |author4=Ruiperez Gonzalez, Maria |author5=Kilibarda, M |author6=Blagotic, A. |author7=Shangguan, W. |author8=Wright, W.M. |author9=Geng, X. |author10=Bauer-Marschallinger, B. |author11=Guevara, M.A. |author12=Geng, X. |author13=Bauer-Marschallinger, B.|author14=Guevara, M.A. |author15=Vargas, R.|author16=MacMillan, R.A.|author17=Batjes, Niels H.| author18=Leenaars, J.G.B.|author19=Wheeler, I.|author20=Mantel, S. |author21=Kempen, B. |year=2017 |title=SoilGrids250m: Global gridded soil information based on machine learning|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=12|issue=2|pages=e0169748|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0169748|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0169748}}</ref> spatial resolution (SoilGrids) produced using automated soil mapping based on machine learning algorithms.
Our on-line resources can be accessed via: * [http://www.isric.org/explore/wosis/ WoSIS - Providing standardised soil profile data for the world (WFS and TXT)] * [http://worldgrids.org/doku.php/wiki:layers/ Worldgrids.org - A repository of gridded predictors with global or at least partial global coverage ] * [http://www.isric.org/explore/soilgrids/ SoilGrids250m - Soil property and class maps for the world at 250m resolution derived from digital soil mapping] * [http://data.isric.org/geonetwork Soil data hub - ISRIC's central location for searching and downloading soil data layers from around the world] * [http://www.isric.org/explore/metadataservice/ Metadata catalogue - Search soil-related metadata from ISRIC and other organisations from around the world] * [http://www.isric.org/explore/library/ World soil library and map collection - On-line search and download facility] * [http://www.isric.org/explore/world-soil-museum/ World soil museum - Take a virtual tour of the museum and reference collections] * [http://www.isric.org/utilise/capacity-building/ Capacity building - Provides an overview of ISRIC's training and educational modules]
[[File:Isric wosis points.png|thumb|Location of soil profiles served from WOSIS (July 2016)]]
==World Data Centre for Soils (WDC - Soils)== ISRIC became a regular member of the '''[[ICSU World Data System]]''' in 2011; it has been a member of the former ICSU [[World Data Center]] since 1989. Within ICSU-WDS, ISRIC is still known as the '''[https://www.icsu-wds.org/community/membership/regular-members/@@member_view?fid=isric-wdc-soils WDC-Soils]'''.
==Useful links== * [http://www.isric.org/ ISRIC - World Soil Information website] * [http://www.icsu-wds.org/ ICSU World Data System (ICS-WDS)] * [https://www.coretrustseal.org/ CoreTrustSeal certified data repositories (CTS)] * [http://www.iuss.org/ International Union of Soil Sciences (IUSS)] * [http://www.fao.org/globalsoilpartnership/en/ Global Soil Partnership (GSP)] * [http://www.globalsoilmap.net/ GlobalSoilMap.net] * [http://www.godan.info/working-groups/soil-data/ GODAN Soil Data Working Group (Global Open Data for Agriculture and Nutrition)] * [http://eusoils.jrc.ec.europa.eu European Soil Data Centre (ESDAC)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131015075637/http://ies.jrc.ec.europa.eu/ Institute for Environment and Sustainability, EC Joint Research Centre (IES-JRC)] * [https://sdmdataaccess.nrcs.usda.gov/ Soil data access, USDA]

[[File:Amerique Septentrionale JBF 1688.jpg|thumb|upright=2|1688 Map of North America with a pictorial view of Quebec City by Franquelin]] '''Jean-Baptiste-Louis Franquelin''' was born at [[Palluau-sur-Indre|Saint-Michel de Villebernin]], [[France]] in 1650.<ref name=born1650/> He died in France around 1712. He was a [[Cartography|cartographer]], a royal [[Hydrography|hydrographer]], and a teacher of navigation. He was also the first official cartographer in Canada.
== Biography == Between 1674 and 1708, Franquelin drew around 50 detailed illustrated manuscript maps of [[New France]]. Franquelin came to Canada as a trader in 1671. [[New France]] Governor [[Louis de Buade de Frontenac]] recognized his talents and recruited him to draw maps. He recorded the explorations of [[Louis Jolliet]] and [[René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle|René-Robert Cavelier de La Salle]] between 1674 and 1684. The King appointed him royal hydrographer in 1688. He went to France in 1692 to complete a series of maps on the [[New England]] coast. He had 13 children, but unfortunately, his wife and ten of his children drowned in a shipwreck in 1693, near of [[Sept-Îles, Quebec|Sept-Iles]], Quebec. He held his Canadian appointment from 1686 to 1697 and again from 1701 to 1703. However, from 1694 to 1707, he worked for [[Louis XIV]]th's military engineer [[Vauban]], and he never returned to Canada.<ref>C.E Heidenrich, ''The Canadian Encyclopedia'', second edition, volume II, Edmonton, Alberta: Hurtig Publishers, 1988, p. 839</ref>
== Works (selection) == * [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b530168677 Map of the Great Lakes]<ref name=chezGallica/> * [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b52501769v ''Carte du grand fleuve St Laurens dressee et dessignee sur les memoires et observations que le Sr. Jolliet a tres exactement faites en barq: et en canot en 46 voyages pendant plusieurs années'']<ref name=chezGallica/><ref name=enItaliques/> — Drawn with [[Louis Jolliet]]'s collaboration * [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/h?ammem/gmd:@field(NUMBER+@band(g3300+ct000656)) Map of Louisiana],<ref name=chezLibCong/> 1684<ref name=voirNewberry/> — See also Google's [http://www.google.ca/search?q=franquelin+map+1684&es_sm=93&tbm=isch&imgil=-qrMVSR3RHtX8M%253A%253BITY6SlypKE9umM%253Bhttp%25253A%25252F%25252Fen.wikipedia.org%25252Fwiki%25252FFile%25253AClip_of_Franquelin%27s_map_of_Louisiana_1684.jpg&source=iu&pf=m&fir=-qrMVSR3RHtX8M%253A%252CITY6SlypKE9umM%252C_&usg=__4PoLE7Q3I7PFDU4WiObuob8_CA8%3D&biw=1360&bih=667&ved=0CDAQyjc&ei=didtVfrfA_HfsATxjoO4BQ#imgrc=-qrMVSR3RHtX8M%253A%3BITY6SlypKE9umM%3Bhttp%253A%252F%252Fupload.wikimedia.org%252Fwikipedia%252Fen%252F1%252F13%252FClip_of_Franquelin's_map_of_Louisiana_1684.jpg%3Bhttp%253A%252F%252Fen.wikipedia.org%252Fwiki%252FFile%253AClip_of_Franquelin's_map_of_Louisiana_1684.jpg%3B700%3B525 presentation]. * [https://books.google.com/books?id=KvtEUChw9uAC&pg=PA64 Carte de France septentrionale]<ref name=dansHayes/> * [[:commons:Category:Jean-Baptiste-Louis Franquelin|Maps]] on [[Wikimedia Commons]]
=== Lists of maps === * See [[#Charbonneau|Charbonneau]], {{p.|46–52}}: 48 maps * [http://www.biblioserver.com/newberry/index.php?m=search&id=20&ftype=author&q=Franquelin 34 maps] at Newberry Library Cartographic Catalog

{{for|the capital city of Indonesia|Jakarta}} {{for|the king of Hawaiʻi|Kalapana of Hawaiʻi}} [[File:A_classical_painting_of_the_Kingdom_of_Shambhala,with_its_capital,_Kalapa,_at_the_centre.jpg|thumb|right|City of Kalapa]] {{for|the locality in Rockhampton Region, Queensland, Australia|Kalapa, Queensland}} {{for|the medieval Buddhist atomistic concept|Rupa-kalapa}}
'''Kalapa''', according to [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] legend, is the capital city of the Kingdom of [[Shambhala]], where the [[Kings of Shambhala|Kulika]] King is said to reign on a lion throne. It is said to be an exceedingly beautiful city, with a sandalwood pleasure grove containing a huge three-dimensional [[Kalachakra]] [[mandala]] made by King [[Suchandra]].
Kalapa Court, the palace of the king, stands on a platform of pearl in the centre. The building is nine stories high. The roof and floor of the king’s chamber consist of crystal plants that radiate heat for warmth. The city is shaped like a square, and surrounded by walls made of ruby. There are four gates for entry made of precious stones. There are 31 pavilions each of which is surrounded by gardens and streams.<ref>The Kalapa Court of Shambhala(2016) Douglas J. Penick, cited from available at http://levekunst.com/the-kalapa-court-of-shambhala/</ref>
There are two half-moon shaped lakes on two sides of Kalapa.<ref>Lepage Victoria(1996) Shambhala: The fascinating Truth Behind the Myth of Shangri-la.Theosophical Publishing House: Illinois.pp 30 </ref>
==References== <references />

revision.text:
{{Dynamic list|date=September 2016}} This is a list of European cities by average temperature (monthly and yearly). The temperatures listed are averages of the daily highs and lows. Thus, the actual daytime temperature in a given month will be {{convert|2|to|10|C-change|F-change|0}} higher than the temperature listed here, depending on how large the [[diurnal temperature variation|difference between daily highs and lows]] is.

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/124.43.122.60|124.43.122.60]] ([[User talk:124.43.122.60|talk]]): Non notable alumni . ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{multiple issues|{{overly detailed|list=yes|date=August 2015}} {{very long|list|date=August 2015}} {{Alumni|date=December 2014}}}} {{Dynamic list}} [[File:Royal_College,_Colombo-Logo.png|right]] This is a list of alumni of [[Royal College Colombo]] in [[Sri Lanka]], often called '''"Old Royalists"'''. {{Quote box |quote = One comes across fellow Royalists in varying situations in life;
instantly a rapport is established for one knows the other
— assumes his qualities and understands his character. |author = [[Lalith Athulathmudali]] |source = |quoted = }} ==Heads of State== [[File:Junius Richard Jayawardana (1906-1996).jpg|thumb|J. R. Jayewardene, President of Sri Lanka|140px]] [[File:Maumoon-Abdul-Gayoom.jpg |thumb|Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, President of the Maldives|140px]] [[File:Sir James Peiris.JPG |thumb|Sir James Peiris, Vice President of the Legislative Council and first Ceylonese Acting Governor|140px]] [[File:Anagarika Dharmapala.jpg |thumb|Anagarika Dharmapala,
Buddhist revivalist and writer|140px]] {{AlumniStart}} {{Alum |name=[[J. R. Jayewardene]] |year= |nota= [[President of Sri Lanka|President]] (1978–1989), [[Prime Minister of Sri Lanka]] (1978–1979), member of [[Sri Lanka Parliament|Parliament]] [[Kelaniya Electoral District|Kelaniya]] (1960), [[Colombo South Electoral District|Colombo South]] (1960–1977), [[Colombo West Electoral District|Colombo West]] (1977–1978) |ref= }} {{Alum |name=[[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]] |year= |nota=[[President of the Maldives]] (1978–2008) |ref= }} {{Alum |name=[[Muhammad Fareed Didi]] |year= |nota= [[List of Sultans of the Maldives|Sultan of the Maldives]] (1954–1968) |ref={{cite web|url=http://www.maldivesroyalfamily.com/maldives_photo_10.shtml |title=Maldive students at Royal College Colombo 1920s |publisher=Maldivesroyalfamily.com |date=16 January 2008|accessdate=10 September 2011}} }} {{AlumniEnd}} ==Heads of Government== {{AlumniStart}} {{Alum |name=[[John Lionel Kotalawela|Sir John Kotalawela]] |year= |nota= [[Prime Minister of Ceylon]] (1953–1956), [[Parliament of Ceylon|member of Parliament]] for [[Dodangaslanda Electoral District|Dodangaslanda]] (1947–1959), [[Legislative Council of Ceylon|member of Legislative Council]] (?–1931), [[State Council of Ceylon|member of State Council]] (1931–1947) |ref= }} {{Alum |name=[[Ranil Wickremesinghe]] |year= |nota=[[Prime Minister of Sri Lanka|Prime Minister]] (1993–1994, 2001–2004, 2015–present) |ref= }} {{AlumniEnd}} ==Royalty== {{AlumniStart}} {{Alum |name=[[Prince]] [[Henveyru Ganduvaru Manippulu]] |year= |nota= [[Crown Prince]] of the [[Maldives]] |ref= }} {{Alum |name=[[Prince]] [[Hassan Farid Didi]] |year= |nota=Minister for Home Affairs, Minister for Finance, Minister of State and Plenipotentiary Representative in Ceylon |ref= }} {{AlumniEnd}} ==Viceregal== {{AlumniStart}} {{Alum |name=[[James Peiris|Sir James Peiris]] |year= |nota= Acting [[Governors of British Ceylon|Governor of Ceylon]] (1925), Vice-President [[Legislative Council of Ceylon]] (1924–1940) |ref=[http://www.atimes.com/ind-pak/CI08Df01.html Chapter 5: SRI LANKA: THE UNTOLD STORY], K.T.Rajasingham [[Asia Times]] Retrieved 7 November 2015 }} {{Alum |name=[[C. Nagalingam]] |year= |nota=Acting [[Governor-General of Ceylon]] (1954), Acting [[Chief Justice of Sri Lanka|Chief Justice of Ceylon]] (1954), [[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Sri Lanka|Supreme Court Judge]] (1947–1958), [[Attorney General of Sri Lanka|Attorney General]] (1946–1947) |ref= }} {{Alum |name=[[David de Kretser]] |year= |nota=[[Governors of Victoria|Governor of Victoria]] (2006–2011) |ref= }} {{AlumniEnd}} ==Prominent figures in the Independence Movement== {{AlumniStart}} {{Alum |name=[[Anagarika Dharmapala]] |year= |nota=Buddhist revivalist and leader of the Sri Lankan independence movement |ref= }} {{Alum |name=[[James Peiris|Sir James Peiris]] |year= |nota=Prominent political leader, first Vice President of the Legislative Council and the first Ceylonese Acting Governor |ref=[https://books.google.com/books?id=jUTf-jaS2xAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn:1463418388&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCEQ6wEwAGoVChMIsfTTtNuAyQIVRqQOCh1eVQi_#v=onepage&q=Peiris%20presided%20over%20Legislative%20Council%20Administering%20Government&f=false PEACE AT LAST IN PARADISE], Ananda Guruge p.213 (AuthorHouse Publishing) {{ISBN|9781463418373}} (note: also listed in Legislators) }} {{Alum |name=[[Fredrick Richard Senanayake|F. R. Senanayake]] |year= |nota=Leader of the Sri Lankan independence movement and member of [[Legislative Council of Ceylon]] (note: also listed in Legislators) |ref= }} {{Alum |name=[[E. W. Perera]] |year= |nota=[[Senate of Ceylon|Senator]], member of Legislative Council and [[State Council of Ceylon|State Council]] |ref= (note: also listed in Legislators) }} {{Alum |name=[[Ponnambalam Ramanathan|Sir Ponnambalam Ramanathan]] |year= |nota=Prominent political leader, [[Solicitor General of Ceylon]] and first member to be elected to the Legislative Council |ref={{cite web |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605192811/http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2008/02/10/jun06.asp |archive-date=2011-06-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }} (note: also listed in Legislators and Civil servants) }} {{Alum |name=[[Ponnambalam Arunachalam|Sir Ponnambalam Arunachalam]] |year= |nota=Prominent political leader of Ceylon, member of the [[Executive Council (Commonwealth countries)|Executive Council]] and Legislative Council |ref= (note: also listed in Legislators) }} {{Alum |name=[[Charles Edgar Corea]] |year= |noa=Prominent leader in the independence movement, figure executed by the British |ref= }} {{Alum |name=[[Charles Alwis Hewavitharana]] |year= |nota=Prominent leader in the independence movement |ref=(note: also listed in Medicine) }} {{Alum {{Alum |name=[[Nicholas Attygalle|Sir Nicholas Attygalle]] |year= |nota=First president [[Senate of Ceylon]] (1953–1960), first Ceylonese [[Chancellor (education)#Vice-chancellor|Vice-Chancellor]] [[University of Ceylon]] (1954–1967), President Ceylon Medical Council |ref= }} {{Alum |name=[[Cyril de Zoysa|Sir Cyril de Zoysa]] |year= |nota=[[President of the Senate of Ceylon]] (1960–1965) |ref= | {{sortname|Duleep|De Chickera}} | [[Church of Ceylon|Anglican]] [[Bishop of Colombo]] (2001–2010) | style="text-align:center;" | |- | {{sortname|Ivan|Corea}} | Rural Dean of Colombo | style="text-align:center;" | |- | {{sortname|Francis Lorenz|Beven}} | [[Archdeacon]] of [[Jaffna Diocese of the Church of South India|Jaffna]] (1925–1935), [[Archdeacon]] of [[Diocese of Colombo|Colombo]] (1935–1947) | style="text-align:center;" |{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchburgherunion.org/genealogy/ancestry-a/JDBU%201959%20Vol%2049%20No%203%20p60-69%20-%20Arndt%20Ancestry(1).pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131008052026/http://www.dutchburgherunion.org/genealogy/ancestry-a/JDBU%201959%20Vol%2049%20No%203%20p60-69%20-%20Arndt%20Ancestry(1).pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=8 October 2013 |title=Genealogy Of The Family Of Arndt Of Ceylon |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=23 February 2012 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchburgherunion.org/genealogy/ancestry-b/JDBU%201952%20Vol%2042%20No%203%20p114-121%20-%20Beven%20Ancestry(1).pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905041537/http://www.dutchburgherunion.org/genealogy/ancestry-b/JDBU%201952%20Vol%2042%20No%203%20p114-121%20-%20Beven%20Ancestry(1).pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 September 2012 |title=Genealogy Of The Family Of Bervent Of Ceylon |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=23 February 2012 }} |- | {{sortname|Neranjan|Wijeyeratne}} | [[Diyawadana Nilame]] (Chief lay Custodian) [[Temple of the Tooth]], [[Kandy]] (1985–2005) | style="text-align:center;" | |} ==Old Royalists in fiction== Many [[fictional characters]] have been described as Old Royalists. These include: * Carlaboy von Bloss from the novel ''[[Carl Muller|Once Upon a Tender Time]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.nation.lk/2008/02/03/special6.htm |title=Sir Christopher Ondaatje looks back at the importance of Carl Muller’s Trilogy |publisher=Nation.lk |date= |accessdate=2011-09-10}} * Allan from the novel (later made into a film) ''[[Kaliyugaya]]'' * Malin from the novel (later made into a film) ''[[Yuganthaya]]'' * Mithra Dias from the novel ''[[Nihal De Silva|The Giniralla Conspiracy]]''[http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/09/02/fea05.htm Revolutionary ardour and its aftermath The Giniralla Conspiracy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070407211800/http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/09/02/fea05.htm |date=2007-04-07 }} * The [[revolutionary]] Kumudu Prasanna from the novel ''The Giniralla Conspiracy'' * Janendra "Janu" Samarawickrama from the novel ''[[Madhubahashini Disanayaka Ratnayaka|There is Something I Have to Tell You]]'' ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Royal College Colombo Alumni}} [[Category:People associated with Royal College, Colombo]] [[Category:Alumni of Royal College, Colombo|*]] [[Category:Lists of Sri Lankan people by school affiliation|Royal College]] [[Category:Colombo-related lists|Royal College]]

page.title: List of accolades received by WALL-E

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of accolades received by ''WALL-E''}} {| class="infobox" style="width: 25em; text-align: left; font-size: 90%; vertical-align: middle;" |+ '''List of awards won by ''WALL-E''''' |- | colspan="3" style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Andrew Stanton and Victor Navone.jpg|233px|]]
Andrew Stanton and Victor Navone holding the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature |- | colspan=3 | {| class="collapsible collapsed" width=100% ! colspan=3 style="background-color: #D9E8FF; text-align: center;" | Awards and nominations |- |- bgcolor=#D9E8FF | style="text-align:center;" | '''Award''' | style="text-align:center; background: #cceecc; text-size:0.9em" width=50| '''Won''' | style="text-align:center; background: #ffccdd; text-size:0.9em" width=50| '''Nominated''' |- |align="center"| ;[[Academy Awards]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|6}} |- |align="center"| ;[[American Cinema Editors]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Animation Kobe]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Annie Awards]] |{{won|0}} |{{nom|7}} |- |align="center"| ;[[ADG Excellence in Production Design Awards|Art Directors Guild Awards]] |{{won|0}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Boston Society of Film Critics]] |{{won|2}} |{{nom|2}} |- |align="center"| ;[[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]] |{{won|2}} |{{nom|4}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Broadcast Film Critics Association|Broadcast Film Critics]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|3}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Cinema Audio Society Awards]] |{{won|0}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Chicago Film Critics Association]] |{{won|4}} |{{nom|5}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Dallas-Fort Worth Film Critics Association Award]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Florida Film Critics Circle Award]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Golden Globe Awards]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|2}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Grammy Awards]] |{{won|2}} |{{nom|3}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Hollywood Film Festival]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Hugo Award]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;Kansas City Film Critics Circle |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Kids' Choice Awards]] |{{won|0}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;Las Vegas Film Critics Society |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Los Angeles Film Critics]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Motion Picture Sound Editors]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[National Board of Review]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[National Movie Awards]] |{{won|2}} |{{nom|2}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Nebula Award]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[New York Film Critics]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Online Film Critics Society]] |{{won|3}} |{{nom|6}} |- |align="center"| ;[[People's Choice Awards]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;Phoenix Film Critics Society |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Producers Guild of America]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[San Diego Film Critics Society]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Satellite Awards]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|4}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Saturn Award]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|2}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Scream Awards]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|3}} |- |align="center"| ;Southeastern Film Critics Association |{{won|1}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Teen Choice Awards]] |{{won|0}} |{{nom|1}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Toronto Film Critics Association]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|3}} |- |align="center"| ;[[Visual Effects Society]] |{{won|3}} |{{nom|3}} |- |align="center"| ;[[World Soundtrack Awards]] |{{won|1}} |{{nom|2}} |} |- bgcolor=#D9E8FF |align="center" colspan="3"| ;'''Total number of wins and nominations''' |- |{{won|'''Totals'''}} |{{won|'''47'''}} |{{nom|'''82'''}} |- bgcolor=#D9E8FF | colspan="3" style="font-size: smaller; text-align:center;" | [[#References|Footnotes]] |} ''[[WALL-E]]'' (promoted with an [[interpunct]] as ''WALL•E'') is an American animation film released in [[2008 in film|2008]] and directed by [[Andrew Stanton]]. [[Walt Disney Pictures]] released it in the United States and Canada on June 27, 2008, grossing $23.1 million on its opening day, and $63 million during its opening weekend in 3,992 theaters, ranking number 1 at the box office.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekend&id=wall-e.htm |title=WALL-E (2008) – Weekend Box Office Results |accessdate=June 29, 2008 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}} It eventually grossed $223 million domestically and $533 million worldwide.{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=wall-e.htm |title=WALL-E (2008) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=August 19, 2017}} ''WALL-E'' was well received, with an approval rating of 96% on the review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]].{{cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/wall_e/?critic=creamcrop | title=WALL-E Movie Reviews | publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | accessdate=September 24, 2008}} The film was nominated for several awards, including seven [[Annie Awards]], six [[Academy Awards]], and two [[Golden Globe Awards]]. ''WALL-E'' did not win any of the Annie Awards, all of them awarded to categories competitor ''[[Kung Fu Panda]]''.{{cite web|title=2008 Annie Award Nominations by Category |publisher=[[Annie Award]]s |url=http://www.annieawards.org/foryourconsideration.html |accessdate=December 2, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202192706/http://www.annieawards.org/foryourconsideration.html |archivedate=December 2, 2008 |df= }} It won the [[Academy Award for Best Animated Feature]] and was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]], [[Academy Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]], [[Academy Award for Best Sound|Sound Mixing]], [[Academy Award for Sound Editing|Sound Editing]] and [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]] at the [[81st Academy Awards]].{{cite news|title=Oscars 2009: The nominees|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=January 22, 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7842438.stm|accessdate=January 22, 2009}} Walt Disney Pictures pushed for an [[Academy Award for Best Picture]] nomination,{{cite news|author=Michael Cieply, Brooks Barnes|title=Studios Are Pushing Box Office Winners as Oscar Contenders|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 27, 2008|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/28/movies/28stud.html?_r=1&oref=slogin|accessdate=October 28, 2008}} but it was not nominated, provoking controversy about the Academy deliberately restricting ''WALL-E'' to the Best Animated Feature category.{{cite web|last=Bandyk |first=Matthew |title=Academy Awards Controversy: Wall-E Gets Snubbed For Best Picture Oscar |url=https://www.usnews.com/blogs/risky-business/2009/01/22/academy-awards-controversy-wall-e-gets-snubbed-for-best-picture-oscar.html |work=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |date=January 22, 2009 |accessdate=January 22, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717180938/http://money.usnews.com/money/blogs/risky-business/2009/01/22/academy-awards-controversy-wall-e-gets-snubbed-for-best-picture-oscar|archivedate=July 17, 2011}} American film critic [[Peter Travers]] commented that "If there was ever a time where an animated feature deserved to be nominated for best picture it's Wall-E."{{cite web |title=Academy accused of snubbing Dark Knight, Wall-E |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/01/23/2473002.htm?section=entertainment |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=January 22, 2009 |accessdate=January 22, 2009}} The feature has won Best Picture from the [[Boston Society of Film Critics]],{{cite news|author=Peter Sciretta|title=AFI’s Top 10 Movies of 2008; Boston Critics Name WALL-E and SlumDog Best Picture|publisher=/film|date=December 14, 2008|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/2008/12/14/afis-top-10-movies-of-2008-boston-critics-name-wall-e-and-slumdog-best-picture/|accessdate=December 15, 2008}} the [[Chicago Film Critics Association]], the [[Online Film Critics Society]],{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7839300.stm|title=Online film critics back Wall-E|publisher=BBC News|date=January 20, 2009|accessdate=January 20, 2009}} and the [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association]], where it became the first animated feature to win that award.{{cite news|author=Justin Chang|title=L.A. critics wired for 'WALL-E'|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=December 9, 2008|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117997085.html?categoryid=13&ref=ra&cs=1|accessdate=December 9, 2008}} It also became the first animated film to win Best Editing for a Comedy or Musical from the [[American Cinema Editors]]. The character WALL-E was listed at #63 on ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]''{{'}}s 2008 online poll of the 100 greatest movie characters.{{cite web|title=The 100 Greatest Movie Characters|work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]|url=http://www.empireonline.com/100-greatest-movie-characters/default.asp?c=63|accessdate=January 12, 2009}} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' listed ''WALL-E'' number 1 in its top 10 movies of 2008, praising the directors' achievement in connecting with a large audience even though the characters have nearly no dialogue.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/2008/top10/article/0,30583,1855948_1863826,00.html|title=Top 10 Movies|last=Corliss|first=Richard |date=December 3, 2008|work=[[Time Magazine|Time]]|accessdate=March 7, 2009}} In early 2010, ''Time'' ranked ''WALL-E'' number 1 in "Best [[2000s in film|Movies of the Decade]]."{{cite news| page.title: List of countries with KFC franchises

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox KFC |logo = KFC world map.svg}} This is a '''list of countries with KFC franchises'''. As of year end 2014, there are 18,875 [[KFC]] outlets in 119 countries and territories across the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=Restaurant counts|url=http://www.yum.com/investors/restcounts.asp|publisher=Yum!|accessdate=April 3, 2014}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated78>http://www.yum.com/annualreport/pdf/2013yumAnnReport.pdf</ref> The first KFC franchise opened in the United States in 1952, and in Canada a year later. The first overseas franchise was established in the United Kingdom in 1974. A large number of Caribbean and developed Western markets entered by the early 1970s. This was followed by expansion throughout the Middle East and developed Asian markets from the mid-1970s and into the 1980s. China was entered in 1987. Expansions were made into most of Europe and South America in the early 1990s. The most recent area of expansion is Africa, where the company is targeting the continent's growing middle class.
The major markets for KFC include China (4,563 units), the United States (4,491 units), Japan (1,181 units), the United Kingdom (900 units), South Africa (736 units), Canada (663 units), Australia (618 units), Russia (608 units), Malaysia (579 units) and Thailand (531 units).
The global operations are overseen by Yum International, which is headquartered in [[Louisville, Kentucky]]. Yum! typically grant a master franchise to a local operator, or take a stake in a joint venture between such a company and itself. In 11 locations, Yum! International manages KFC directly, including China, Russia and India.<ref>http://www.taiwantoday.tw/ct.asp?xitem=84549&CtNode=415</ref> Worldwide, major franchise holders range from large local [[conglomerate (company)|conglomerates]] such as [[Jardine Matheson]] and [[Doosan Group]], to companies specifically established to run restaurants franchises, such as [[AmRest]]. In Japan, Malaysia and Indonesia, the major franchise holders are [[publicly listed company|publicly listed companies]]. On the other hand, in smaller markets such as some Caribbean islands, the franchises may be operated by a single individual.
==Current markets==

Divested its holdings from 1987 until 1994 to a holding company after U.S. Congress passed a law forbidding U.S. companies from owning South African assets.<ref>The Associated Press June 20, 1994, Monday, BC cycle Kentucky Fried Chicken Returns to South Africa</ref> KFC sold its assets to Devco, an administrative entity, which managed the trademark.<ref>Agence France Presse – English June 20, 1994 05:15 Eastern Time Kentucky Fried Chicken re-invests in South Africa</ref> |- | {{Flagcountry|Tanzania}} || 2013<ref name=autogenerated78 /> || || First outlet opened in [[Dar es Salaam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.24tanzania.com/kfc-restaurant-makes-debut-in-dar/|title=KFC restaurant makes debut in Dar - 24Tanzania.com|date=May 1, 2013|work=24tanzania.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> |- | {{Flagcountry|Tunisia}} || 2018<ref name=KFCopensfirstrestaurantinTunisia>{{cite news|title=KFC opens first restaurant in Tunisia|url=http://www.businessnews.com.tn/kfc-ouvre-son-premier-restaurant-en-tunisie,520,77207,3|accessdate=January 10, 2018|newspaper=Businessnews.com.tn|date=January 9, 2018}}</ref> || HBG group || 2 outlets in [[Lac 1]] and [[La Marsa]]. |- | {{Flagcountry|Uganda}} || 2013|| Kuku Foods East Africa<ref>[http://www.observer.ug/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=29790:kfc-raises-the-stakes-in-chicken-market&catid=79:businesstopstories&Itemid=68 The Observer – KFC raises the stakes in chicken market<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> || First outlet opened in [[Kampala]]. |- | {{Flagcountry|Zambia}} || 2011<ref name=lusaka>{{cite news|title=KFC arrival signifies Zambia's global clout – First Lady|url=http://www.lusakatimes.com/2011/03/26/kfc-arrival-signifies-zambias-global-clout-lady/|accessdate=September 25, 2013|newspaper=lusakatimes.com|date=March 26, 2011}}</ref> || || By the end of 2011, four outlets had been opened in shopping centres in the capital city of [[Lusaka]]. |- |}
