===Asia=== [[File:Vietnamese KFC.jpg|thumb|right|A KFC in [[Ho Chi Minh City]], Vietnam]] [[File:KFC in SM Aura, BGC.jpg|thumb|right|KFC in [[Bonifacio Global City]], [[Philippines]]]] [[File:KFC Polayathode, Kollam city.jpg|thumb|right|KFC in [[Polayathode]], [[Kollam]] city; one of the largest KFC stores in [[Kerala]] state, [[India]]]] [[File:A KFC outlet in Colombo, Sri Lanka.png|thumb|right|A KFC outlet in [[Colombo]], [[Sri Lanka]]]] {|class="wikitable sortable" style="width:75%" |- ! style="width:20%" | Country ! style="width:10%" | Year{{br}}entered ! style="width:20%" | Owner/major operator ! style="width:50%" | Notes |- | {{Flagcountry|Azerbaijan}} || 2011<ref name=January>{{cite news|last=Shaheldiyev|first=Suleyman|title=AZERBAIJAN is the home to the world's largest KFC.|url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-909429|work=CNN|accessdate=November 19, 2013|date=|year=2013}}</ref> || AFK Ltd<ref name=January /> || In October 2012, the world's largest KFC opened in [[Baku]]. The 1,600-square-meter outlet, with a [[seating capacity]] of 300, is housed in the city's [[Sabunçu, Baku|Sabunçu]] rail station built in 1926. AFK Ltd reportedly invested 3 million euros to restore the nearly destroyed building.<ref>{{cite web|title=World's largest KFC restaurant opened in Baku|url=http://abc.az/eng/news/69111.html|work=ABC.az|accessdate=November 19, 2013|date=October 29, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413132102/http://abc.az/eng/news/69111.html|archivedate=April 13, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Largest KFC in the World Is in Baku|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/kfc-biggest-in-the-world-baku-azerbaijan/24768712.html|work=Radio Free Europe Radio Liberty|accessdate=November 19, 2013|date=November 12, 2012}}</ref> 8 outlets.<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> |- | {{Flagcountry|Bangladesh}} || 2006<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=http://www.kfcbd.com|title=KFC Bangladesh|website=www.kfcbd.com|access-date=January 17, 2017}}</ref> || [[Transcom Group]]<ref name="auto"/> || First outlet opened at [[Gulshan Thana|Gulshan]] in 2006. As of 2018, there are 24 outlets; 21 in [[Dhaka]], 1 in [[Chittagong]], 1 in [[Sylhet]] and 1 in [[Cox's Bazar]]. |- | {{Flagcountry|Brunei}} || 1992{{fact|date=April 2018}} || ||15 outlets. |- | {{Flagcountry|China}} || 1987<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/english/200011/28/eng20001128_56364.html|title=KFC Open's 400th Restaurant in China|website=english.people.com.cn|access-date=April 7, 2016}}</ref> || KFC China<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://knowledge.insead.edu/leadership-management/strategy/kfc-chinas-recipe-for-success-1706|title=KFC China's recipe for success|website=INSEAD Knowledge|access-date=April 7, 2016}}</ref> || KFC's largest market. The first Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet opened on Qianmen Street in downtown Beijing in 1987.<ref name="autogenerated8">[http://english.people.com.cn/english/200011/28/eng20001128_56364.html KFC Open's 400th Restaurant in China<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> 5138 outlets.<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> |- | {{Flagcountry|Cambodia}} || 2008 ||The Royal Group|| Established in March 2008. KFC is one of Royal Group of Companies Ltd (The Royal Group) business, a partnership with the Malaysian QSR brands and Rightlink Corporation.The Royal Group is one of the largest conglomerates in Cambodia with substantial investments in media, telecommunications, banking, education, property development and trading. Cambodia boasts only eleven branches of KFC. Ten of these are clustered in the capital Pnomh Penh. |- | {{Flagcountry|Hong Kong}} || 1985<ref name="INSEAD Knowledge">{{Cite web|url=http://knowledge.insead.edu/KFCinChina090323.cfm?vid=195|title=INSEAD Knowledge|website=INSEAD Knowledge|access-date=April 7, 2016}}</ref> || Birdland Ltd<ref name="INSEAD Knowledge"/> || KFC was the first American fast food chain to enter Hong Kong in 1973, with an outlet in [[Mei Foo Sun Chuen]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Hong Kong Management: Cases in Marketing|year=1996|publisher=Chinese University Press|isbn=978-962-201-724-5|pages=3–4}}</ref> There were 11 outlets by mid-1974, but by September 1974 many outlets had closed.<ref name=autogenerated61>{{cite book|title=Hong Kong Management: Cases in Marketing|year=1996|publisher=Chinese University Press|isbn=978-962-201-724-5|page=4}}</ref> The remaining 4 outlets were closed in February 1975. KFC misjudged the local market and failed to develop a suitable business model, with its takeout only stores failing to catch on.<ref name=autogenerated15>| {{Flagcountry|Bangladesh}} || [https://archive.is/20130925131836/http://www.transcombd.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5.. Transcom Foods Ltd<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Chickens imported from China were fed fishmeal, which ruined the taste.<ref name=autogenerated15 /> The chain was reintroduced by [[Swire Group]] in September 1985, with an outlet opened on [[Jordan Road, Hong Kong|Jordan Road]], at a cost of $3 million.<ref name=autogenerated14>{{cite book|title=Hong Kong Management: Cases in Marketing|year=1996|publisher=Chinese University Press|isbn=978-962-201-724-5|page=5}}</ref> A second outlet was opened on [[Causeway Bay]] in 1986.<ref name=autogenerated14 /> By 1995 there were 17 outlets.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hong Kong Management: Cases in Marketing|year=1996|publisher=Chinese University Press|isbn=978-962-201-724-5|page=7}}</ref> Sold to Birdland in 1997.<ref name=autogenerated14 /> 163 outlets.<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> |- | {{Flagcountry|India}} || 1995<ref name="TichyMcGill1997">{{cite book|author1=Tichy, Noel M.|author2=McGill, Andrew R.|author3=St. Clair, Lynda|title=Corporate Global Citizenship: Doing Business in the Public Eye|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bUU2enYFbzEC&pg=PA332|accessdate=July 10, 2012|year=1997|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=978-0-7879-1095-2|pages=331–2}}</ref> || KFC India || KFC opened a two-storey outlet on [[Brigade Road]] in [[Bangalore]] in June.<ref name="TichyMcGill1997"/> 372 outlets.<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> |- | {{Flagcountry|Indonesia}} || 1979<ref name=Indonesia>{{cite web|title=KFC Indonesia|url=http://www.kfcku.com |publisher=KFC Indonesia |accessdate=April 3, 2018 }}</ref> || PT Fastfood Indonesia<ref name=Indonesia /> || First outlet in Jalan Melawai, [[Jakarta]].<ref name=Indonesia /> Listed on the [[Jakarta Stock Exchange]].<ref name=Indonesia /> 465 outlets.<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> The owner is currently owned by PT Indoritel Makmur Internasional, which is also owned [[Indomaret]]. See [http://www.kfcku.com/ KFC Indonesia] |- | {{Flagcountry|Japan}} || 1960<ref name=autogenerated59>The Japan Economic Journal July 21, 1990 ON A WING AND A PRAYER; After a rocky start, Kentucky Fried is devouring Japan 7</ref> || KFC Holdings Japan, Ltd<ref>[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=9873:JP KFC HOLDINGS JAPAN LTD (9873:Tokyo): Stock Quote & Company Profile – Businessweek<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ||First outlet opened in [[Kobe]].<ref name=autogenerated59 /> 1181 outlets.<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> |- | {{Flagcountry|Kazakhstan}} || 2010 || [[Americana Group]]<ref name=autogenerated41 /> || 49 outlets. |- | {{Flagcountry|Kyrgyzstan}} || 2017 || || 3 outlets in [[Bishkek]]. |- | {{Flagcountry|Laos}} || 2016{{fact|date=December 2017}} || || |- ||{{Flagcountry|Macau}} |||| || This KFC is located in the Galaxy Casino. See [https://www.galaxymacau.com/en/macau-restaurant/restaurant-directory/quick-bites/kfc KFC Macau] |- | {{Flagcountry|Malaysia}} || 1973<ref name=autogenerated54>[http://www.kfc.com.my/about-kfc-malaysia.php KFC – About KFC – KFC Malaysia<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120621113352/http://www.kfc.com.my/about-kfc-malaysia.php |date=June 21, 2012 }}</ref> || QSR Brands (M) Holdings Sdn Bhd<ref name=autogenerated76>{{cite web|url=http://www.qsrbrands.com/|title=Home - QSR Brands|work=qsrbrands.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> ||The first KFC outlet was opened in 1973 on [[Jalan Tunku Abdul Rahman]]. There are over 600 KFC restaurants as for 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kfc.com.my/kfc-malaysia|title=KFC Malaysia|last=|first=|date=|website=KFC Malaysia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Kentucky Nuggets was conceived in Malaysia and then found its way to KFC worldwide. Today, Kentucky Nuggets is one of KFC's successes.<ref>[http://www.kfc.com.my/about-kfc-malaysia.php About KFC<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120621113352/http://www.kfc.com.my/about-kfc-malaysia.php |date=June 21, 2012 }}</ref> KFC led the chained fast food market in 2011, with 41 percent of value sales.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euromonitor.com/fast-food-in-malaysia/report|title=Fast Food in Malaysia|work=euromonitor.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> |- |{{Flagicon|Maldives}} [[Maldives]] |2018 |Gama Island Food Pvt Ltd |First outlet opened in Galolhu district of [[Malé|Malè]] |- | {{Flagcountry|Mongolia}} || 2013<ref name=autogenerated56>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2013/02/26/kfc-mongolias-latest-first-mover/#axzz2MfVylWEl|title=KFC: Mongolia’s latest “first mover”|work=ft.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> || Tavan Bogd Group<ref name=autogenerated28>{{cite web|title=Restaurants & Franchises|url=http://www.dodsal.com/food/projects.shtml|publisher=Dodsal Group|accessdate=February 14, 2013}}</ref>|| 17 outlets. See [http://www.kfcmongolia.com/ KFC Mongol] |- | {{Flagcountry|Myanmar}} || 2015 || || One outlet open in [[Yangon]] in June 30.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/kfc-becomes-first-us-fast-food-chain-in-myanmar/2842721.html|title=KFC Becomes First US Fast-food Chain in Myanmar|first=VOA|last=News|work=voanews.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> 27 outlets by November 20, 2018. |- | {{Flagcountry|Nepal}} || 2009<ref name=autogenerated12>[http://www.myrepublica.com/portal/index.php?action=news_details&news_id=46968 KFC imports from Thailand to keep business going MYREPUBLICA.com – News in Nepal: Fast, Full & Factual, POLITICAL AFFAIRS, BUSINESS & ECONOMY, SOCIAL AFFAIRS, LIFESTYLE, SPORT...<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> || Devyani International<ref name=autogenerated12 /> || Seven outlets: Six in [[Kathmandu]],<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> at [[Durbar Marg|DurbarMargh]] , Boudha, Thimi, Maharajgunj, Labim Mall, BlueBird mall, Tripureshwar. One in [[Pokhara]] (Lakeside).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.myrepublica.com/news/19338/|title=KFC in Pokhara|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> |- | {{Flagcountry|Pakistan}} || 1997<ref name=autogenerated29>{{cite web|url=http://www.kfcpakistan.com/about-kfc.html|title=URL is unreachable|work=kfcpakistan.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809053347/http://kfcpakistan.com/about-kfc.html|archivedate=August 9, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> || Cupola Group<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kfcpakistan.com/about-cupola.html|title=URL is unreachable|work=kfcpakistan.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810050552/http://kfcpakistan.com/about-cupola.html|archivedate=August 10, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> || First entered Pakistan in the late 1960s to early 1970s but subsequently closed down.<ref>{{cite book|last=Sanders|first=Harland|title=The Incredible Colonel|year=1974|publisher=Creation House|location=Illinois}}</ref> Reopened in [[Gulshan-e-Iqbal]] in [[Karachi]] in 1997.<ref name=autogenerated29 /> 62 outlets.<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> |- | {{Flagcountry|Philippines}} || 1967<ref name="Smith2011">{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Andrew F.|title=Fast Food and Junk Food: An Encyclopedia of What We Love to Eat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wq3tvL_uIHcC&pg=PA549|accessdate=July 5, 2013|year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-39394-5|page=549}}</ref> || Wholesome Foods Inc<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/business/manitoba-kfctaco-bell-outlets-get-new-calgary-owner-159684095.html|title=Manitoba KFC/Taco Bell outlets get new Calgary owner|work=winnipegfreepress.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> || 237 outlets.<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> In June 1994, Manuel U. Agustines obtained the sole franchise over the sale and distribution of KFC products in the Philippines, under the corporate name of Quick Service Restaurants (QSR) Corporation. |- | {{Flagcountry|Singapore}} || 1977<ref name=autogenerated16>[http://www.kfc.com.sg/about-us-milestone.php About Us Milestone – Welcome to KFC<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> || QSR Brands (M) Holdings Sdn Bhd<ref name=autogenerated71>{{cite web|url=http://www.qsrbrands.com/about/|title=About Us - QSR Brands|work=qsrbrands.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> || First outlet opened on Somerset Road in 1977.<ref name=autogenerated16 /> 40 stores by 1992, when it was acquired by KFC International.<ref name=autogenerated19>[http://www.kfc.com.sg/milestone2 About Us Milestone – Welcome to KFC<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428174446/http://www.kfc.com.sg/milestone2 |date=April 28, 2016 }}</ref> In 2002, KFC Singapore was acquired by KFC (Malaysia) Holdings Bhd.<ref name=autogenerated19 /> 83 outlets in 2012.<ref name=autogenerated13>[http://www.jcorp.com.my/kfc-56.aspx KFC | Johor Corporation<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927195503/http://www.jcorp.com.my/kfc-56.aspx |date=September 27, 2013 }}</ref> |- | {{Flagcountry|South Korea}} || 1984<ref name=autogenerated42>{{cite web|url=http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/AK/AK_EN_1_4_9_4.jsp|title=Official Site of Korea Tourism Org.: Yasik Culture (Late-night Meals)|work=visitkorea.or.kr|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> || [[Doosan Group]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doosan.com/en/intro/affiliate.jsp|title=Doosan Global : Companies & Brands|first=|last=null|work=doosan.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> || KFC Korea had a good startoff in the beginning, but has experienced a decline in the mid-2000s. Opening its first store in 1984 in [[Jongno]] of the capital [[Seoul]], the outlet number has increased with its 100th store at Mokdong of Seoul (1996), and its 200th store near [[Seoul National University|Seoul University]] (2000).<ref>{{cite web|title=4. Beyond the Headlines – Bermuda<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> || First KFC restaurant on Queen Street, [[Hamilton, Bermuda|Hamilton]].<ref name=autogenerated51>{{cite web|url=http://www.kfc.bm/about|title=KFC in Bermuda - About Us|first=|last=TMC|work=kfc.bm|accessdate=February 1, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322154035/http://kfc.bm/about|archivedate=March 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> There is just one outlet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bernews.com/2013/12/kfc-bermuda-undergoing-major-remodeling/|title=KFC Bermuda Undergoing Major Remodeling - Bernews.com|date=December 1, 2013|work=bernews.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> |- |{{Flagcountry|Canada}} || 1953<ref name=autogenerated43>[http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/758221/kfc-canada-finds-its-soul-mate KFC CANADA | KFC Canada Finds its Soul Mate<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928120111/http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/758221/kfc-canada-finds-its-soul-mate |date=September 28, 2013 }}</ref> || Yum Restaurants International (Canada)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kfc.ca/|title=KFC.ca - It’s Finger Lickin’ Good|work=kfc.ca|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> || 636 outlets. First restaurant in [[Calgary]].<ref name=autogenerated43/> Branded PFK (''Poulet Frit Kentucky'') in the province of [[Quebec]], the only such alteration of the trademark in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kfc.ca/story.aspx?lang=fr|title=Notre Histoire -Histoire de PFK, le Colonel Harland Sanders - PFK Québec|work=kfc.ca|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> |- |{{Flagcountry|Mexico}} || 1965<ref name=autogenerated72>[http://www.kfc.com.mx/historia.php Kfc | Home<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806061310/http://kfc.com.mx/historia.php |date=August 6, 2013 }}</ref> || Premium Restaurant Brands<ref name=autogenerated27 /> || 322 outlets.<ref name=autogenerated18 /> First outlet opened in [[Monterrey]].<ref name=autogenerated27 /> |- |{{Flagcountry|United States}} ||1930 || ||4,232 outlets. The franchise first opened in [[Salt Lake City]], Utah in 1952. |} {{Clear}}

===Asia=== {|class="wikitable sortable" style="width:75%" |- ! style="width:20%" | Country ! style="width:10%" | Year{{br}}existed ! style="width:20%" | Owner ! style="width:50%" | Notes |- |{{Flagcountry|Iran}} || || || The franchise was abandoned in Iran following the 1979 Islamic revolution.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nrn.com/archive/yum-no-plans-open-kfc-restaurants-iran|title=Yum: 'No plans to open KFC restaurants in Iran'|website=nrn.com|access-date=April 7, 2016}}</ref> KFC had stressed that two stores that opened in [[Karaj]] in 2012 and [[Mashhad]] in 2014 under the KFC name were not affiliated with the company.<ref name=autogenerated39 /> |- | {{Flagcountry|Israel}} || 1993 - 2014<ref name=autogenerated7>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/KFC%20TO%20OPEN%20IN%20ISRAEL-a014243355|title=KFC TO OPEN IN ISRAEL - Free Online Library|work=thefreelibrary.com|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> || [[KFC Israel|Clal Trading Limited]]<ref name="thefreelibrary.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/KFC+TO+OPEN+IN+ISRAEL-a014243355|title=KFC TO OPEN IN ISRAEL - Free Online Library|website=www.thefreelibrary.com|access-date=April 7, 2016}}</ref> || First store in [[Rishon LeZion]].<ref name="thefreelibrary.com"/> |- | {{Flagcountry|Yemen}} || 2009-2016 || || One outlet, temporarily shut down.<ref name=globalrestaurantsystem /> |}

==Future markets== {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible" style="width:75%" |- ! style="width:20%" | Country ! style="width:10%" | Year ! style="width:20%" | Owner ! style="width:50%" | Notes |- |{{Flagcountry|Ethiopia}} || 2019 || |kaldi’s group |-KFC will open its first location in Addis in April 29 2019 |{{Flagcountry|Gabon}} |2019 | |Opening first KFC outlet in Libreville.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} |- |{{Flagcountry|Rwanda}} |2018 | |{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} |- |{{Flagcountry|Belgium}} || 2018 || || Opened in the late 1970s, but closed due to declining sales.<ref>The New York Times September 14, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition EXPORTS: THE DECLINE OF THE AMERICAN MANAGER</ref> In November 2016, it was announced that KFC will reopen in Belgium, but the first location has yet to be determined.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} |- |{{Flagcountry|Israel}} || 2019 || || Operated in Israel from 1993 to 2012. KFC plans to re-enter the Israeli market in 2019 due to popularity of the chain operating in the past.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/251262|title=KFC returning to Israel|website=Israel National News|language=en|access-date=2018-08-30}}</ref> |- |- |{{Flag|Senegal}} |2018 |TBA |Opening 2 restaurants in Dakar<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/548912/economie/fast-food-apres-la-tunisie-et-la-cote-divoire-kfc-debarque-au-senegal/|title=Fast-food : après la Tunisie et la Côte d’Ivoire, KFC débarque au Sénégal – JeuneAfrique.com|website=JeuneAfrique.com|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-08-25}}</ref> |- |{{Flag|Sudan}} |2018 |Araak Group<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.alnilin.com/12959601.htm|title=قريباً .. (كنتاكي) و (بيتزا هت) في السودان|website=www.alnilin.com|language=ar-AR|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref> |- |{{Flagcountry|Finland}} |2019 | |KFC will be coming to Finland in 2019 and its project is to open more than 50 restaurants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iltalehti.fi/ruoka-artikkelit/09fa766c-a455-49c1-b253-04e57f3ba31d_rh.shtml|title=Kohta jonotetaan kanaämpäreitä? {{Other uses}} [[File:Percival Harrison Fawcett.jpg|thumb|The British surveyor [[Percy Fawcett]] in 1911, who believed an indigenous city, which he called "the Lost City of Z", had existed in the Brazilian jungle.]] The '''Lost City of Z''' is the name given by [[Percy Fawcett|Col. Percy Harrison Fawcett]], a [[United Kingdom|British]] surveyor, to an indigenous city that he believed had existed in the jungle of the [[Mato Grosso]] state of [[Brazil]]. Based on early histories of South America and his own explorations of the [[Amazon River]] region, Fawcett theorized that a complex civilization once existed there, and that isolated ruins may have survived.<ref name="Grann NYer">{{cite journal|last=Grann|first=David|author-link=David Grann|date=September 19, 2005|title=The Lost City of Z|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/09/19/the-lost-city-of-z|journal=[[The New Yorker]]|volume=LXXXI|issue=28|pages=56–81|issn=0028-792X}}</ref>
==History== Fawcett found a document known as {{Interlanguage link|Manuscript 512|pt|Manuscrito 512}}, held at the [[National Library of Brazil]], believed to have been written by Portuguese ''[[bandeirante]]'', João da Silva Guimarães. Da Silva wrote that during 1753, he had discovered the ruins of an ancient city that contained arches, a statue, and a temple with [[hieroglyphics]]. He described the city ruins in great detail without giving its location.
''Manuscript 512'' was written after explorations made in the [[sertão]] of the province of [[Bahia]].{{efn-lr|name="expl"|group="n"|See Fawcett's book ''Exploration Fawcett'' (1953).}} Fawcett intended to pursue finding this city as a secondary goal after "Z". He was preparing an expedition to find "Z" when [[World War I]] broke out and the British government suspended its support (Fawcett returned to Britain and served on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] during the war). In 1920, Fawcett undertook a personal expedition to find the city, but withdrew after suffering a fever and having to shoot his pack animal.<ref name="Grann NYer" /> On a second expedition five years later, Fawcett, his son Jack, and Jack's friend Raleigh Rimell, disappeared in the Mato Grosso jungle.
==Possible influences on Fawcett== Researchers believe that Fawcett may have been influenced in his thinking by information he might have obtained from indigenous people about the [[archaeological]] site of [[Kuhikugu]], near the headwaters of the [[Xingu River]].<ref name="Grann book">{{cite book|first=David|last=Grann|authorlink=David Grann|date=2009|isbn=978-0-385-51353-1|title=The Lost City of Z: A Tale of Deadly Obsession in the Amazon|publisher=Doubleday|year=|location=|pages=|title-link=The Lost City of Z (book)}}</ref> Kuhikugu was discovered by Westerners after Fawcett's presumed death in the jungle in 1925. The site contains the ruins of an estimated twenty towns and villages in which as many as 50,000 people might once have lived.
== In popular culture == In 2005, the American journalist [[David Grann]] published an article in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' on Fawcett's expeditions and findings, called "The Lost City of Z".<ref name="Grann NYer" /> In 2009, he developed it into a [[The Lost City of Z (book)|book of the same title]], and in 2016, it was adapted by writer-director [[James Gray (director)|James Gray]] into a [[The Lost City of Z (film)|film also of the same name]] starring [[Charlie Hunnam]], [[Robert Pattinson]], and [[Sienna Miller]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/james-grays-the-lost-city-of-z-starts-shooting-marvels-spider-man-tom-holland-joins-the-cast-20150819|title=James Gray's 'The Lost City Of Z' Starts Shooting, Marvel's Spider-Man Tom Holland Joins The Cast|last=Jagernauth|first=Kevin|date=August 19, 2015|website=IndieWire|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2017-12-15}}</ref>
In the 2018 video game ''[[Shadow of the Tomb Raider]]'', [[Lara Croft]] uncovers relics of Fawcett's final doomed search of the Lost City considerably farther west in [[Peru]].
== Recent development == The discovery of large geometrical earthworks in interfluvial settings of southern Amazonia support Fawcett’s theory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-018-03510-7|title=Pre-Columbian earth-builders settled along the entire southern rim of the Amazon|last=Jonas Gregorio de Souza et. al|date=March 27, 2018|website=Nature.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-03-29}}</ref>

{{Infobox website | name = MapmyIndia | headquarters = Okhla Phase-III, New Delhi{{cite book|author=K.S.V. Menon & Garima Malik|title=Funding Options for Startups: A Conceptual Framework and Practical Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bARTDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT29|date=10 June 2016|publisher=Notion Press|isbn=978-1-945400-80-3|pages=29}} | screenshot = File:MapmyIndia.jpg | type = IoT, Navigation, Maps, GIS Services | founded = {{Start date and age|1992}} | founder = Rakesh Verma, Rashmi Verma | area_served = Indian subcontinent | key_people = Shivalik Prasad (Executive Director), Rohan Verma (Director), Sapna Ahuja (COO), Anuj Jain (CFO) | industry = [[Cartography|Mapping data]]
[[GPS navigation software]]
[[Web mapping]] | owner = CE Info Systems Pvt Ltd. | num_employees = 1000+{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} | website = {{URL|https://www.mapmyindia.com}} }} '''MapmyIndia''' offers digital map data, [[telematics]], location-based [[SaaS]] and [[GIS]] services.{{cite web|author=Our Bureau |url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/info-tech/mapmyindia-to-build-digital-map-twin-of-the-real-world/article9644671.ece |title=MapmyIndia to build ‘Digital Map Twin of the Real World’ | Business Line |publisher=Thehindubusinessline.com |date=2017-04-17 |accessdate=2017-08-21}}{{cite web|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/industry/technology/mapmyindia-this-navigation-system-will-help-you-reach-the-doorstep-of-your-destination-heres-how/546020/ |title=MapMyIndia: This navigation system will help you reach the doorstep of your destination; here's how |publisher=The Financial Express |date=2017-02-10 |accessdate=2017-08-21}} The company was founded in 1992 and is headquartered at [[New Delhi]].{{cite book|author=K.S.V. Menon & Garima Malik|title=Funding Options for Startups: A Conceptual Framework and Practical Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bARTDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT29|date=10 June 2016|publisher=Notion Press|isbn=978-1-945400-80-3|pages=29}} ==History== MapmyIndia is founded by Rakesh and Rashmi Verma in 1992.{{Cite news|url=https://inc42.com/startups/mapmyindia-maps-gps/|title=MapmyIndia Story: The 25 Year Journey Of Maps, GPS, And More|date=2017-06-13|work=Inc42 Media|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}} They launched a startup called C E Info Systems in 1992 at New Delhi, India.{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/small-biz/startups/as-mapmyindia-enters-google-territory-can-it-beat-the-goliath-of-internet/articleshow/63060134.cms|title=As MapmyIndia enters Google territory, can it beat the Goliath of internet?|last=Layak|first=Suman|date=2018-02-25|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-10-29}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/04/24/business/corporate-business/japanese-map-publisher-zenrins-indian-partner-expansion-drive/|title=Japanese map publisher Zenrin’s Indian partner in expansion drive|date=2017-04-24|work=The Japan Times Online|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US|issn=0447-5763}} The company started working upon developing a [[web mapping]] technology and provide products and services required for enhancing marketing and logistics efficiency in existing organisations in the country.{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbesindia.com/article/startups/mapmyindia-2.0-battling-for-supremacy/49999/1|title=MapmyIndia 2.0: Battling for supremacy {{!}} Forbes India|website=Forbes India|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-29}} In 1993 the company took up an assignment to develop good quality maps with detailed topography to support the marketing and logistics operations of Coca-Cola and Cellular One.{{cite article|title=Harvard Business Review,https://hbr.org/2013/07/use-customer-cash-to-finance-your-start-up}} The company launched the first Indian interactive digital mapping portal "www.mapmyindia.com" in 2004.{{Cite web|url=https://www.afaqs.com/news/story/50075_Meet-MapmyIndia-the-Desi-Google-Map|title=Meet MapmyIndia, the 'Desi Google Map'|website=www.afaqs.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-29}} This portal provided free, customized, [[location-based services]] including assigning an e-location to existing addresses to enable last mile deliveries to their exact destinations. The services were available for mobile phones with internet connectivity also. These services were also provided through the MapmyIndia portal to [[MagicBricks]].{{cite article|title=The Economic Times,https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/internet/locate-your-house-with-mapmyindia-v-2007/articleshow/2173135.cms}} In 2010, MapmyIndia launched a GPS navigation service called Road Pilot, preloaded with Indian cities, villages and destinations.{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/mapmyindia-launches-new-gps-navigator/articleshow/5675759.cms|title=MapmyIndia launches new GPS navigator|date=2010-03-12|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-10-29}} The company's Mapsare integrated with [[ISRO]] Satellite Imagery for detailed satellite and hybrid.{{Cite news|url=https://auto.ndtv.com/news/mapmyindia-launches-digital-twin-of-real-world-1682517|title=MapMyIndia Launches Digital Twin Of Real World - NDTV CarAndBike|last=|first=|date=|work=[[NDTV]]|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}} As of 2018, it has 5000+ Enterprises and 5mn+ consumers that use and benefit from its services. MapmyIndia has also expanded into the Indian subcontinent by creating maps of Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Nepal.{{Cite web|url=https://www.medianama.com/2014/05/223-mapmyindia-launches-new-app-with-voice-navigation-in-regional-languages/|title=Mapmyindia launches new app with voice navigation in regional languages - MediaNama|website=www.medianama.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-29}} ==Product and services== MapmyIndia offers [[Navigation]], Tracking, [[Internet of things|IoT]], Analytics and [[web mapping]] service for desktop and mobile devices.{{Cite web|url=https://www.financialexpress.com/industry/how-mapmyindia-is-planning-rival-to-google-maps/1019664/|title=How MapmyIndia is planning rival to Google Maps - The Financial Express|website=www.financialexpress.com|access-date=2018-10-29}} The company also offers advanced [[Vehicle tracking system|GPS tracking devices]], car in-dash infotainment, plug & play on-board diagnostics car tracker and rear seat entertainment.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/info-tech/mapmyindia-to-launch-vehicle-tracking-device/article24857333.ece|title=MapmyIndia to launch vehicle-tracking device|work=@businessline|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/business/2018/oct/21/mapmyindia-expects-30-per-cent-revenue-growth-this-fiscal-on-account-of-new-products-1888085.html|title=MapmyIndia to launch vehicle-tracking device|last=|first=|date=3 September 2018|website=|publisher=[[The Hindu]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The navigation service features street view, public transit information and turn-by-turn navigation with spoken instructions for vehicles. It later launched offline navigation app, Navimaps that uses offline vector data to offer 3D terrains and city models & 3D building for in-car infotainment systems.{{Cite news|url=https://gadgets.ndtv.com/apps/news/mapmyindia-navimaps-navigation-app-for-ios-now-available-for-download-566679|title=MapmyIndia 'NaviMaps' Navigation App for iOS Now Available for Download|work=NDTV Gadgets360.com|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bgr.in/news/mapmyindia-launches-navimaps-an-offline-navigation-app-for-ios/|title=MapmyIndia launches ‘NaviMaps’, an offline navigation app for iOS|last=PTI|date=2014-07-29|work=BGR India|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mysmartprice.com/gear/2018/07/20/android-auto-app-satellite-view-google-maps-realistic-true-car-navigation-mode/|title=Android Auto App Gets Satellite View: Google Maps Finally Looks Realistic While In True In-Car Navigation Mode - MySmartPrice News|date=2018-07-20|work=MySmartPrice|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}} ==Market share== The company's navigation service is primarily used by the car manufacturers and it has 90% market share on [[GPS navigation]] in India.{{Cite web|url=https://www.financialexpress.com/industry/car-gps-devices-what-is-better-smartphone-or-dedicated-device-here-is-guide-for-you/930291/|title=Car GPS devices: What is better? Smartphone or dedicated device; here is guide for you - The Financial Express|website=www.financialexpress.com|access-date=2018-10-29}} It also claims to have 5,000 enterprise customers with 80% market share in the location intelligence space.{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/it-majors-to-benefit-from-regulatory-push-for-telematics/articleshow/58136318.cms|title=IT majors to benefit from regulatory push for telematics - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-10-29}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.vccircle.com/flipkart-backed-mapmyindia-acquires-vidteq|title=Flipkart-backed MapmyIndia acquires VIDTEQ|date=2017-04-18|work=VCCircle|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}} ==Funding== MapmyIndia has raised $34 million in venture capital financing in the three rounds since 2007 from the Lightbox Ventures, Nexus Venture Partners,{{Cite web|url=https://gigaom.com/2007/08/09/419-mapmyindia-gets-over-25-million-in-funding-from-nexus-india-capital/|title=MapMyIndia Gets Over $2.5 Million In Funding From Nexus India Capital|last=Staff|first=Edit|date=2007-08-09|website=gigaom.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-29}} Qualcomm Ventures and Zenrin.{{Cite news|url=https://www.outlookbusiness.com/enterprise/big-idea/an-atlas-of-opportunity-1730|title=An atlas of opportunity|last=|first=|date=|work=Outlook|access-date=2018-10-29}} In 2015, [[Flipkart]] announced that it has acquired 34% stake of the company for Rs 1,600 crores.{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/small-biz/startups/flipkart-picking-up-34-stake-in-digital-mapping-firm-mapmyindia-in-rs-1600-crore-deal/articleshow/50034934.cms|title=Flipkart picking up 34% stake in digital mapping firm MapmyIndia in Rs 1,600 crore deal|last=Chanchani|first=Madhav|date=2015-12-04|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-10-29|last2=Dave|first2=Sachin}} == References == {{reflist}} {{Earth}} [[Category:Web mapping]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2005]] [[Category:Street view services]] [[Category:Indian websites]] {{software-stub}}
